related_facts.fact_group_content: Productivity growth averaged roughly 1.5% from 2007 to 2019.
The most optimistic projections for AI's impact on productivity growth are about 1% per year.
AI could move productivity growth from 1.5% to 2.5%.
The impact of all artificial intelligence would increase by 15 to 40 percent.
Generative AI could enable labor productivity growth of 0.1 to 0.6 percent annually through 2040.
50% likelihood of AGI being developed between 2040 and 2065.
18% of participants believe AGI development would be existentially catastrophic.

clusters.title: Future Productivity
clusters.description: AI is projected to significantly influence productivity growth, potentially increasing it from 1.5% to 2.5%. Despite the optimistic projections, there are concerns about the development of Artificial General Intelligence (AGI), with a 50% likelihood of AGI emerging between 2040 and 2065 and 18% of experts worried about existential risks. Generative AI is anticipated to contribute an additional 0.1 to 0.6% to productivity annually until 2040.

clusters.title: Generative Value
clusters.description: Generative AI has the potential to significantly boost economic value across various industries. In the banking sector, it could contribute between $200 billion to $340 billion annually, while in retail and consumer packaged goods, the annual value could range from $400 billion to $660 billion. Key areas such as customer operations, marketing, sales, software engineering, and R&D are expected to comprise around 75% of the total value generated by generative AI applications. However, the environmental impact of training large models is noteworthy, with emissions reaching approximately 315 tons of carbon dioxide per model.

Work automation could add 0.5 to 3.4 percentage points annually to productivity growth.
Technology has the potential to automate half of the time employees spend working.

clusters.title: Automation Inequality
clusters.description: Digital technologies have significantly contributed to the increase in between-group inequality in the United States since 1980, with automation accounting for 50% to 70% of this rise.
